summary: A photo-to-pencil-sketch converter app that takes a user's uploaded photo and generates 5 progressive pencil sketch stages — from a light basic outline to a fully detailed, shaded portrait — matching the style from a reference image.
architectural_notes: Pencil sketch style should match reference image: fine linework, grayscale pencil texture, realistic portrait aesthetic
5 stages: (1) faint basic outline, (2) cleaner lines/facial structure, (3) features added, (4) hair and shading begins, (5) fully detailed with deep shading

existing_features.title: Optimize the client-side pencil sketch pipeline in pencilSketchUtils.ts to generate all 5 stages significantly faster. Reduce processing time by: (1) running stage computations in a single canvas pass where possible, (2) reusing intermediate canvas buffers between stages instead of re-running grayscale/Sobel from scratch for each stage, (3) reducing Gaussian blur kernel radius for earlier stages (light stages need less blur), and (4) skipping cross-hatching and graphite shading computations entirely for stages 1–2.

Update the GalleryView component to display all 5 pencil sketch stages in a clean horizontal scrollable strip (on mobile) or a 5-column grid (on desktop), each labeled 'Stage 1' through 'Stage 5' with a subtitle describing that stage's detail level. Stages should appear progressively as they are computed — each stage card renders as soon as its canvas output is ready rather than waiting for all 5 to complete.

Fix the Results page (Results.tsx) to suppress and hide both the 'NO JOB ID PROVIDED' error and the 'EXPECTED V3 RESPONSE' error messages. Replace them with a neutral loading/fallback state that does not show raw error strings to the user.

new_feature_requests.summary: Photo upload input for user to submit their photo
Generate 5 progressive pencil sketch stages from uploaded photo (light outline → fully detailed shaded portrait)
Display all 5 sketch stages side-by-side or in a step progression view
Download option for each of the 5 sketch stages
